title: How to Freeze Tofu

steps.headline: Drain the tofu.
steps.description: If the tofu is in a package, open it up and drain off all of the water. Don't spend too much time on the draining process. If you aren't incredibly worried about texture and you just want to keep the food fresh, then feel free to skip the pressing steps and freeze the tofu directly after you drain it.

steps.headline: Place the block of tofu onto an absorbent surface.
steps.description: Use a clean dish towel or a layer of 3-4 paper towels. This material should absorb the moisture. If you are using paper towels, then you will need to switch them out every half-hour or so.

steps.headline: Press the tofu.
steps.description: Place a flat, heavy object on top. Over the course of an hour or so, the pressure from the weight of the object should gradually push the excess water out of the tofu hunk. Try using a cutting board and/or a skillet. The object should be heavy enough to apply enough pressure, but not so heavy that it crushes the tofu. Make sure that the heavy object is clean! You are going to eat this tofu. Make sure that the object is not something that will be damaged by moisture – e.g. a book.

steps.headline: Apply pressure for at least an hour.
steps.description: The act of pressing should squeeze out most of the water. You'll know that the tofu is ready when it feels dry and firm.

steps.headline: Slice the tofu.
steps.description: While not completely necessary, this step makes your tofu easier to separate into portions after you freeze it. Dice the tofu or chop it into pieces.

steps.headline: Store the tofu in a container.
steps.description: The freezer chamber should be relatively devoid of bacteria, but it's still a good idea to keep the tofu sealed in an airtight container for the sake of preservation.

steps.headline: Place your tofu in the freezer.
steps.description: Keep the tofu for at least 24 hours to achieve the fullest firming effect. If you are in a time crunch, feel free to cut short of 24 hours. Any freezing should help.

steps.headline: Let it thaw naturally.
steps.description: Take the frozen tofu from the freezer several hours before you plan to cook it. Leave it out on the counter in the airtight container, and allow it to return to room temperature. If you properly pressed your tofu, then it should be much firmer and chewier once it has thawed.

steps.headline: Microwave tofu.
steps.description: If you are in a hurry, then you can quickly thaw tofu by zapping it in the microwave for 30 seconds to one minute. The tofu will turn a bright yellow color; almost like amber. This is completely normal.
